author: By Meredith Kolodner
title: Why Does New York State Sue Its College Students?
description: Thousands of SUNY students have been taken to court by the attorney general’s office over tuition debt. And through a quirk in the law, the only way they can defend themselves is by appearing before a judge in Albany.
content: Amanda Belony was rushing to work when she saw a fat yellow envelope left for her on her mother’s kitchen table. She opened it and immediately noticed the New York attorney general’s official seal sitting ominously at the top of the page. The state had filed a lawsuit against her for unpaid college tuition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Bianca Andreescu Returns to the U.S. Open With Winning on Her Mind
description: Dogged by injuries, the 2019 champion didn’t play a single match last year, but the young Canadian has surrounded herself with a new team focused on keeping her healthy.
content: So much has changed since her first visit, but Bianca Andreescu is still undefeated at the U.S. Open, where she swept to the 2019 title in precociously grand style, defeating Serena Williams in straight sets in the final at age 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Kellen Browning
title: Apple delays the rollout of child-safety features over privacy concerns.
description: Apple had not expected the kind of backlash the new features faced.
content: Apple said on Friday that it would delay its rollout of child safety measures, which would have allowed it to scan users’ iPhones to detect images of child sexual abuse, after criticism from privacy groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: How Shang-Chi, Master of Kung Fu, Knocked Down Stereotypes
description: The Marvel superhero originated in comics filled with racist tropes. The creators of the new film made a list of the preconceptions they were up against and set out to conquer them.
content: In the pantheon of Marvel superheroes, there’s Spider-Man and Iron Man and Captain America and … Shang-Chi?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cornered in Rooms or Cars by Torrents of Water, Dozens Are Found Dead
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 3, 2021.
content: “I tried to hold on to my wife and she was trying to hold on to me. But the water pushed me away and I couldn’t feel her hand anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Musicals Return to Broadway With ‘Waitress’ and ‘Hadestown’
description: The song-and-dance shows that are Broadway’s bread and butter began a staggered return to the stage Thursday. For audiences, vaccinations and masks were mandatory.
content: Sara Bareilles stepped onto the stage of the Ethel Barrymore Theater a few minutes after 7 p.m. Thursday, a white apron over her blue uniform, as a looped recording of her voice began to intone pie ingredients. “Sugar. Sugar. Sugar, butter. Sugar, butter. Sugar, butter, flour.” And then, with a single note from a keyboard, a high piano chord and a whoosh from a cymbal, she launched into a song about baking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: When Chance Encounters at the Water Cooler Are Most Useful
description: Research suggests that initially meeting in person is helpful, especially for people who don’t work closely.
content: A key scientific breakthrough that would eventually help protect millions from Covid-19 began with a chance meeting at a photocopier — in 1997, between Professor Katalin Kariko and Dr. Drew Weissman, whose work laid the foundation for the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Ben Sisario
title: Drake and Kanye West, Long Intertwined, Will Tangle on the Charts
description: The rappers’ anticipated albums, “Certified Lover Boy” and “Donda” — both potential streaming blockbusters — arrived within five days of each other, with very different rollouts.
content: For more than a decade, Drake and Kanye West have been locked in a dialogue at the top of the hip-hop heap — occasional collaborators turned friendly competitors turned bitter rivals, and sometimes all three at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Japan’s Prime Minister Will Step Aside After Just a Year in Office
description: Yoshihide Suga’s abrupt decision came after he had spent days trying to salvage a historically unpopular administration.
content: TOKYO — Less than a year after becoming prime minister of Japan, Yoshihide Suga said on Friday that he would not seek re-election as the head of its governing party, raising the prospect of a return to the revolving-door leadership that once characterized the top office of the world’s third-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Very Successful Matchmaking Mission
description: Valerie Persinger and Michael Webster were set up by her sister and brother-in-law, who also happened to be the groom’s Navy commander at the time.
content: Valerie Persinger and Michael Webster were targets of an unlikely matchmaking pair: her sister and his former boss, who happened to be married to one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: We Know How to Teach Kids to Read
description: Shelve the fad methods. There’s one tried-and-true way, and it works for children of all races and classes.
content: It was great to see Zaila Avant-garde become the first Black American winner of the Scripps National Spelling Bee in July. But in broader view, it’d be better if there were no such thing as a spelling bee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Stephen Vizinczey, ‘In Praise of Older Women’ Author, Dies at 88
description: His best-known work, somewhat scandalous for the mid-1960s, treated sex frankly and sold millions of copies.
content: Stephen Vizinczey, whose novel “In Praise of Older Women,” about a man’s sexual education by paramours not in his age bracket, caused a stir in the mid-1960s and became a cultural reference point, died on Aug. 18 at his home in London. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Ex-Nurse Pleads Guilty to Sexually Assaulting Patient in Vegetative State
description: Nathan Sutherland, a former nurse at an Hacienda HealthCare facility in Phoenix, pleaded guilty to assaulting a woman in his care who later gave birth to his child.
content: A former Arizona nurse accused of abusing a woman in a vegetative state who had been in his care and who later gave birth to his child pleaded guilty on Thursday to sexual assault, according to the Maricopa County Attorney’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: The Nigerian Activist Trying to Sell Plants to the Oil Company That Destroyed Them
description: “I need to help my women to stand,” says Martha Agbani, who helped a group of women from the Niger Delta build a flourishing mangrove nursery.
content: YAATAAH, Nigeria — When the women arrived in the quiet, waterside village of Yaataah on an afternoon in May, some local young men hurried over to them. They offered to carry the women’s loads — old rice sacks and tin basins full of seeds, ready for planting — down to the swamp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody García and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Guatemala Investigates Claim of Bribe Paid to Its President
description: A previous inquiry was cut short when the chief anti-corruption prosecutor was fired, but media reports of cash payments have prompted another one.
content: GUATEMALA CITY — Guatemalan prosecutors have opened an investigation into allegations that Russian citizens paid a bribe to the nation’s president, Alejandro Giammattei, a spokesman for the attorney general’s office said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘The Doors Didn’t Open Easily’ on Her Path to ‘Cinderella’
description: The choreographer JoAnn M. Hunter has quietly become an important figure in the world of musical theater, especially with her work for Andrew Lloyd Webber.
content: LONDON — Midway through Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new “Cinderella,” the male ensemble throws itself into a thrusting, muscle-popping number that perfectly illustrates the musical’s fictional setting of Belleville, a town devoted to beauty in all its superficial forms. It’s also laugh-out-loud hilarious, a sly take on an objectification more usually embodied by a female chorus, and a witty amplification of the musical’s reimagining of the Cinderella myth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: White House Seeks $65 Billion for ‘Apollo’ Plan to Prepare for Future Pandemics
description: The plan calls for an initial investment of at least $15 billion — half of what President Biden initially proposed.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House, stepping into delicate negotiations on Capitol Hill over funding to prevent future pandemics, unveiled on Friday a $65.3 billion preparedness plan that it likened to the Apollo missions to the moon, and called on Congress to immediately invest at least $15 billion for the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: Recipes for a Little Joy
description: Caramelized zucchini pasta, slow-cooker tinga chicken tacos and more meals that are as simple as they are fun to make.
content: What a week. How’s everyone doing out there? I’ve been thinking of those affected by Hurricane Ida (and everything else). And I hope you are doing OK. We had some flooding, lost some treasured things. But my family is safe, and we are grateful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Movie Fans Repeated ‘Candyman.’ But Not the Name of Its Director.
description: Bernard Rose followed up his 1992 horror classic with a Beethoven biopic and four Tolstoy adaptations. Will the new sequel give him another shot?
content: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — At first there weren’t a lot of people besides the writer-director Bernard Rose who thought it was a good idea to make the title villain of the 1992 film “Candyman” Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Wear a Family Heirloom Without It Looking Like a Costume?
description: A reader wants to get married in her father’s waistcoat, but she doesn’t want to look too … theatrical.
content: First, congratulations on your wedding. These rituals are gestures of faith in the future and optimism in what often seems like a very gloomy world. Wearing one of your father’s favorite garments is a lovely twist on that whole “something old/something new/something borrowed/something blue” adage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Lara Jakes and Eileen Sullivan
title: Inside the Afghan Evacuation: Rogue Flights, Crowded Tents, Hope and Chaos
description: President Biden has insisted that the evacuation of Kabul was done as efficiently as possible. But key documents obtained by The New York Times suggest otherwise.
content: WASHINGTON — On the last day of August, when President Biden called the airlift of refugees from Kabul an “extraordinary success,” senior diplomats and military officers in Doha, Qatar, emailed out a daily situation report marked “sensitive but unclassified.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Friday
description: Naomi Osaka and Aryna Sabalenka feature as the third round of singles action begins.
content: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN; 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app. In Canada on TSN from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; and streaming on TSN.ca and the TSN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amia Srinivasan
title: What’s Wrong With Sex Between Professors and Students? It’s Not What You Think.
description: We need to get beyond evaluating sex solely through the lens of consent.
content: Netflix’s new hit comedy “The Chair” revels in certain clichés of university life — mock-Gothic buildings, wood paneling, crusty old-timers who don’t know how to use a photocopier, and, of course, an ambiguous relationship between a professor and a student: Bill is a charismatic English professor who is in a tailspin after the death of his wife, and Dafna is a literature-loving undergrad who is desperate to get into Bill’s class. She gives him a ride; they quote T.S. Eliot to each other; he signs a copy of his book for her; she makes him a pie. We think we know where this is going, because we’ve seen it so many times before: in “Election” (1999), “The Squid and the Whale” (2005) and “Elegy” (2008), based on Philip Roth’s novel “The Dying Animal” — to take just a few recent examples. “The Chair” ultimately upends our expectations in a way that is both comic and poignant. Don’t have sex with me, Dafna in effect says to Bill: Teach me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Companies Stay Quiet on Texas’ New Abortion Law
description: Businesses that expressed opposition to restrictive voting laws are declining to take a similar stand on the abortion measure.
content: When Texas lawmakers advanced a restrictive voting rights bill this year, American Airlines and Dell Technologies, two of the state’s biggest employers, were early and vocal critics of the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: In the Dead of Night, the Supreme Court Proved It Has Too Much Power
description: The conservative majority essentially nullified the constitutional rights of millions of American women without so much as an argument.
content: The Supreme Court’s recent reliance on the so-called shadow docket to make major rulings — on display, this week, in its decision to let Texas end legal abortion after six weeks, at least for now — throws the problem of judicial power in a representative democracy into sharp relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Is Your ‘Go Bag’ Ready?
description: Climate-related emergencies like hurricanes, fires and floods are becoming more frequent. Here’s how to prepare whether you need to evacuate or hunker down.
content: Emergencies often are unpredictable. But you can still plan for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At the U.S. Open, Tennis Moves on as the Kids Make Noise
description: Carlos Alcaraz shocked Stefanos Tsitsipas on Friday. Then Leylah Fernandez stunned Naomi Osaka. On Saturday, the fast-rising Emma Raducanu gets her chance at the final 16.
content: For years, tennis has been asking itself how it will move on as its biggest stars head for the exits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why Newsom Is Telling California Voters to Leave Half the Ballot Blank
description: The second question on the recall ballot is confusing and distressing many Democrats.
content: Unlike the sprawling forms Californians usually contend with in the voting booths, the ballots for the recall election of Gov. Gavin Newsom ask only two questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: Weak Job Gains Leave Washington on High Alert
description: The Federal Reserve and White House had hoped for strong job gains, and the August report did not deliver. That makes coming numbers critical.
content: Disappointing August jobs numbers intensified the economic uncertainty caused by the Delta variant, putting pressure on the Federal Reserve as it considers when to reduce its policy support and on the White House as it tries to get more Americans vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Manhattan-Centric No More, at Least Online
description: Tiana Idoni-Matthews met Nate Koppel, from Woodside, Queens, on JSwipe after extending her dating radius from five to 25 miles.
content: Tiana Ehinome Idoni-Matthews, who lived on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, connected with Nathaniel Wagner Koppel, who lived in Woodside, Queens, on the dating app JSwipe in January 2017 after she extended her Manhattan-centric dating radius from five to 25 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why Not Offer a Remote Option for School?
description: Vaccine hesitancy remains strong, while students under 12 are still vulnerable.
content: At the outset of the pandemic last year, two of Ruth Horry’s three children got sick with Covid — one of them, just 5, frighteningly so, with a fever that raged for days and required hospitalization. “It got to the point where she was at 105 and shaking and we couldn’t even get in a cab,’’ Ms. Horry told me. “They wouldn’t take us. She was coughing and people were scared; this was a time when everyone was basically wearing garbage bags.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilberto Neto and Ruth Maclean
title: Waste From Mine in Angola Kills 12 Downstream in Congo, Minister Says
description: Toxic metals from Angola’s largest diamond mine spilled into the Kasai River in July, sickening thousands and causing an “environmental catastrophe,” researchers said.
content: LUANDA, Angola — First, the river turned red. Then dead fish by the ton floated up to the surface. Then thousands of people started getting sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Moyn
title: America Is Giving the World a Disturbing New Kind of War
description: The withdrawal from Afghanistan is a final step in the transformation of American warfare into something sanitized and edited out of view.
content: In a speech on Tuesday, President Biden identified his decision to withdraw from Afghanistan with his desire to end the “forever war.” But he also promised that America will “maintain the fight against terrorism in Afghanistan and in other countries.” The reality today, he said, is that “we don’t need to fight a ground war to do it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: Here’s what to do if your home flooded during Ida.
description: Answers to frequently-asked questions about cleanup and getting reimbursed for damaged possessions.
content: The remnants of Hurricane Ida and resulting flood on Wednesday dealt a blow to the greater New York region — claiming at least 46 lives, damaging property and rendering homes uninhabitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Cahalan, Andrea Kannapell and Alison Saldanha
title: Covid snapshot: Today’s case, hospitalization, death and vaccination numbers for the U.S.
description: Oregon, Hawaii, South Carolina and have reported more cases in the past week than in any other seven-day period. Weekly deaths in Florida are at record highs.
content: Over the past week, an average of roughly 163,600 coronavirus cases has been reported each day in the United States, an increase of 12 percent from two weeks ago. Total cases are likely to surpass 40 million within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us About Your Grocery Store’s Ethnic Aisle
description: We want to hear from shoppers across the United States who frequent stores that have an ethnic or international food aisle. Is it helpful? Do you find it outdated?
content: Why do we still have the ethnic aisle in American grocery stores? According to a recent article by Priya Krishna, a Food reporter, the issue is complicated. While to many shoppers, it may seem excluding and antiquated, to others, it is a helpful place to find familiar ingredients or discover new ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grant Snider
title: Yoga for Readers
description: Sometimes you can combine what’s good for your mind with what’s good for your body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Michaux
title: At the Tour Championship, Bryson DeChambeau Can Hear Himself Think
description: Sheriff’s deputies and security personnel shadowed the golfer during his first round to enforce a new PGA Tour ban on fans who heckle him. No one dared.
content: ATLANTA — A Tour Championship crowd at East Lake Golf Club will never be confused with a gallery at the Waste Management Open in Phoenix, but on this particular Thursday, the scene could have been mistaken for a solitary stroll in a park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Happens When Jobless Benefits Shrink
description: Job seekers are more likely to accept an offer when their extra federal jobless benefits expire.
content: Americans did not seem to stream back to work in July when federal unemployment benefits in some states became less generous. Studies found “at most a modest increase in employment in states that abandoned the programs,” Ben Casselman of The New York Times reported on Aug. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Former Prosecutor in Ahmaud Arbery’s Death Faces Criminal Charges
description: Jackie Johnson was indicted by a grand jury in Glynn County, Ga., on charges of “violation of oath of public officer” and “obstruction and hindering a law enforcement officer.”
content: A grand jury indicted a former prosecutor in Georgia on Thursday, accusing her of “showing favor and affection” to one of the men now charged with killing Ahmaud Arbery and for directing police officers not to arrest another suspect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: New in Paperback: ‘What You Are Going Through,’ ‘Finding Freedom’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: LITTLE CRUELTIES, by Liz Nugent. (Gallery/Scout Press, 352 pp., $16.99.) Sarah Lyall found this Irish thriller about the extremely unpleasant, possibly homicidal Drumm brothers “clever,” adding, “One of the delights, if that is the right word, of this book is how thoroughly the author delves into the details of the family’s world-class dysfunction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: When Eggplant Meets Eggs
description: This silky end-of-summer dish, reminiscent in some ways of shakshuka, is run through with spiced eggplant, tomatoes and herbs.
content: One of the biggest compromises I had to make with my husband, Daniel, back when we were dating was about eggplant. I realized he hated it, so I avoided cooking it for our together meals for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Facebook Apologizes After A.I. Puts ‘Primates’ Label on Video of Black Men
description: Facebook called it “an unacceptable error.” The company has struggled with other issues related to race.
content: Facebook users who recently watched a video from a British tabloid featuring Black men saw an automated prompt from the social network that asked if they would like to “keep seeing videos about Primates,” causing the company to investigate and disable the artificial intelligence-powered feature that pushed the message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliot A. Cohen
title: The Navy SEAL Who Went Rogue
description: David Philipps’s “Alpha” tells the story of an out-of-control Navy officer who won the protection of Donald Trump and escaped a murder charge.
content: ALPHAEddie Gallagher and the War for the Soul of the Navy SEALsBy David Philipps
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Vaccine Passports Roll Out, and So Do Unruly Anti-Vaccine Protests
description: Protesters have harassed health care workers in three provinces, as well as politicians.
content: A crowd rallying against vaccination for Covid-19 clogged the streets outside a Vancouver hospital this week, haranguing and, in one case, assaulting health care workers, slowing ambulances, delaying patients entering for treatment and disturbing those recovering inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Rulings Without Explanations
description: Why is the Supreme Court using its “shadow docket” so often?
content: The Supreme Court opinion allowing Texas to ban nearly all abortions was different from most major rulings by the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: He Melted Her Heart on the Ice. Twice.
description: Max Fruchter told Natalie Dicker all the reasons he liked her while they went ice skating. Two years later, at a rink with rose petals, he proposed.
content: Natalie Rose Dicker ran out to greet Max Elliot Fruchter with a friendly hug in July 2019 as he walked up the path to her parents’ front door in Great Neck, N.Y.,  for their first date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden’s 10-year pandemic preparedness plan includes a full-time ‘Mission Control’ office.
description: The plan would help agencies spot emerging threats, beef up needed stockpiles and guard against future outbreaks.
content: The White House on Friday unveiled a $65.3 billion, 10-year pandemic preparedness plan that it likened to the Apollo mission to the moon. It called on Congress to immediately allocate at least $15 billion in the budget reconciliation bill for the effort — half the amount President Biden initially proposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Brad Plumer
title: After a Summer of Disasters, Some Lawmakers See a Chance for Climate Action
description: Congress is considering bills to help communities prepare for extreme weather and to cut the greenhouse gases that are driving climate change. But passage is not assured.
content: WASHINGTON — As the country reels from the cascade of deaths and devastation wrought by this summer’s record floods, heat waves, droughts and wildfires, President Biden and progressive Democrats are using the moment to push for aggressive climate provisions in a sweeping $3.5 trillion budget bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Reuniting an Orphan Elephant and Her Mom, Perhaps, With DNA and Luck
description: Nania beat the odds to survive separation from her forest elephant family in Burkina Faso. Her caretakers hope DNA testing may help return her to the wild with her family.
content: The elephant was alone and dehydrated when villagers first found her. It was September 2017, and the motherless mammal wandering near Boromo in Burkina Faso was only 2 or 3 months old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and José Bautista
title: Married Kremlin Spies, a Shadowy Mission to Moscow and Unrest in Catalonia
description: Intelligence files suggest an aide to a top Catalan separatist sought help from Russia in the struggle to break with Spain. A fierce new protest group emerged shortly afterward.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — In the spring of 2019, an emissary of Catalonia’s top separatist leader traveled to Moscow in search of a political lifeline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This No-Bake Cheesecake Is Devastatingly Good
description: Honeydew and cantaloupe become ideal for dessert when cream and sugar enhance their natural sweetness.
content: There’s a running gag about honeydew on the Netflix animated series “BoJack Horseman.” In a string of jabs, the hapless melon is trodden on as “garbage fruit,” cantaloupe’s “dumb friend.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Apple is suddenly giving up ground to app developers.
description: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.
content: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.

author: By Liam Stack
title: Floodwaters rose around a Queens woman in a wheelchair. Then a dramatic rescue.
description: A woman with advanced Alzheimer’s was trapped in her garden apartment before her health aide and neighbors teamed up to help.
content: Essence Crockett was wrapping up a visit to her mother, who has advanced Alzheimer’s disease, when she heard her mother’s home health aide scream from the other side of the garden apartment in Forest Hills, Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Moves to Declassify Some Documents Related to Sept. 11
description: In an executive order, the president instructed Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to publicly release the declassified documents over the next six months.
content: WASHINGTON — Making good on a campaign promise, President Biden directed the Justice Department and other federal agencies on Friday to oversee the review and declassification of documents related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Commerce Dept. Will Shutter Unit That Conducted Rogue Investigations
description: An internal inquiry found that the office improperly opened investigations and overstepped its legal authority, but stopped short of attributing the problems to racial or ethnic bias.
content: WASHINGTON — The Commerce Department plans to shut down a little-known internal security unit that came under scrutiny by Congress for conducting rogue surveillance and investigations into people of Chinese and Middle Eastern descent, department officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A lethal storm in the northeastern U.S.
content: The remnants of Hurricane Ida killed at least 43 people in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut and left more than 150,000 homes without power. States of emergency were still in effect as of midday yesterday, as officials sought to get a handle on the damage. Here are the latest updates and photos from the storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariana Labbate and Slone Terranella
title: Ode to the Flex Desk
description: As interns with this unit, a little-known team of journalists who read Times articles before you do, we learned lessons in writing we’ll never forget.
content: The first questions we were asked as interns at The New York Times were usually: “What do you do there? Where can I see your work?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: In Gap Between Rich and Poor, Everton’s Women See an Opening
description: A series of changes, big and small, has a strengthened Everton believing it can hold its own with deep-pocketed rivals in England’s Women’s Super League.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — Some of the changes have been small, so small as to be imperceptible, at least from the outside. This summer, for the first time, Everton hired someone specifically to take care of the uniforms of its women’s team. It is the sort of thing that serves as a reminder that, in women’s soccer, many little battles are still being won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: British officials seek a way around a vaccine watchdog’s denial of Covid shots for all 12- to 15-year-olds.
description: Health ministers have requested assessments from other medical officials, raising the possibility that the government could take the rare step of defying the vaccine regulator’s advice.
content: Britain’s vaccine watchdog declined on Friday to endorse Covid shots to all children between 12 and 15 years old, advising the government that the health benefits were only “marginally greater than the potential known harms,” and the margin was “too small to support universal Covid-19 vaccination for this age group at this time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Taking Aim at Novak Djokovic, Kei Nishikori Wants a Streak of His Own
description: The world’s No. 1 has beaten his third-round opponent in 16 straight matches. The unseeded Japanese player is optimistic. But he’s not delusional.
content: It was one of the most famous retorts in tennis history, a perfectly executed overhead slam of a quote from the self-deprecating prince of the tour, Vitas Gerulaitis. Going into his match against Jimmy Connors at the 1979 Masters, Gerulaitis had lost 16 straight matches to the lefty, but pulled off the upset at Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles Names a Co-Leader
description: After a period of turmoil, Johanna Burton was tapped as MOCA’s executive director. She will work with the museum’s former director, Klaus Biesenbach, who is now its artistic director.
content: LOS ANGELES — Johanna Burton, the head of the Wexner Center for the Arts at the Ohio State University, has been named the executive director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which she will now help lead after a period of turmoil and management upheavals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: N.H.L. Players Are Set to Return to the Olympics
description: After missing the 2018 Winter Games, the best hockey players in the world will be able to participate in 2022 in Beijing.
content: After missing out on the 2018 Games, N.H.L. players will return to the Winter Olympics in Beijing in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks deal more with inner turmoil and isolation than space exploration.
content: While science fiction can explore galaxies far, far away and offer interstellar spectacles, it is often most challenging when it stays close to home and investigates what makes us human. This month’s selection of overlooked sci-fi streaming movies takes a particular interest in our bodies, ourselves, but don’t worry, the laser battles will come back soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Tips for Victims of Unemployment Benefit Fraud
description: The problem emerged early in the pandemic and shows no signs of slowing down, identity theft experts say. Here’s what to do.
content: Have you received an unsolicited debit card in the mail? Or a letter seeking extra details for an application for unemployment insurance that you don’t recall filing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Wage gains remained strong in August as hiring slowed.
description: Average hourly earnings increased rapidly, including for leisure and hospitality workers, even as job gains fell short of expectations.
content: Wages continued to grow briskly in August even as hiring decelerated, a surprising development that economists said was probably driven partly by continuing demand for workers in spite of coronavirus outbreaks caused by the Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: The Work-From-Home Economy and the Urban Job Outlook
description: Offices are unlikely to be as full after the pandemic as they were before. Service businesses and their employees will have to adapt.
content: Restaurant Associates is not the company it used to be. It has long operated restaurants, catered events and run corporate dining rooms for clients including Google and the Smithsonian Institution. Now it employs about half of the 10,000 or so people it had on staff before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Winegarner
title: ‘The Battery’s Dead’: Burnout Looks Different in Autistic Adults
description: Though little studied, exhaustion among people with autism has become its own pandemic.
content: Tyla Grant, 24, holds down a full-time advertising job, is trying to get a nonprofit off the ground and creates regular content for her podcast, YouTube channel and Instagram. Occasionally, she winds up so fried she can’t speak or get out of bed for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How Lady Gaga’s Mother and the Head of Her Foundation Spends Sundays
description: If someone secretly pays for your coffee this month, it might be Cynthia Germanotta.
content: Born This Way Foundation, founded by Lady Gaga and her mother, Cynthia Germanotta, who is its president, focuses on mental health initiatives for young people. Its annual #BeKind21 campaign, which encourages participants to perform a daily act of kindness, either toward themselves or to others, started on the first of the month and is running through Sept. 21. “One young woman wrote in and thanked us because she chose those 21 days not to harm herself,” Ms. Germanotta said. “That was courageous and amazing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 7: What’s the Matter With Ted?
description: Also: Nate seems headed to a dark place, and Keeley and Roy explore whether there can be too much of a good thing.
content: At last: A clear vision of the trajectory of this season — hinted at last week — has come into focus. It’s not about wins and losses. We still have no idea of AFC Richmond’s chances of rejoining the Premier League. We don’t even know their next opponent in the FA Cup, following last week’s shocking upset of Tottenham Hotspur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: How Does Kristen Stewart Play Princess Diana?
description: The star of “Spencer” may be one of the few actresses with an inkling of what it’s like to be so often hounded by the paparazzi.
content: While watching the new film “Spencer,” which premiered Friday at the Venice Film Festival, I kept pondering Kristen Stewart’s long, unlikely association with the fashion house Chanel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Robert Jimison, Lynsea Garrison, Lisa Chow and Dan Powell
title: How Texas Banned Almost All Abortions
description: Legislation banning most terminations has gone into effect in Texas. How did it avoid being immediately struck down like so many previous anti-abortion laws?
content: In a way, the new Texas law that has effectively banned abortions after six weeks is typical — many other Republican-led states have sought to ban abortions after six, 10 or 15 weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Hiring Slowdown in August Shows Delta Variant’s Impact
description: Employers added 235,000 jobs, one of the weakest showings of the past year. Work involving in-person contact with customers was particularly affected.
content: The American economy stumbled in August as the latest coronavirus wave forced employers to curtail hiring in the sectors that had spearheaded the job market’s recent resurgence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in September
description: Our picks for September, including ‘Billions,’ ‘Goliath’ and ‘Worth’
content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Most of the apartments where New Yorkers drowned were illegal residences.
description: Four of the five basement apartments where people were killed in Queens were illegal conversions, as was one in Brooklyn, the Department of Buildings said.
content: New York City’s Department of Buildings said Friday that five of the six houses in which New Yorkers were killed by Wednesday’s flood were illegally converted cellar or basement apartments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Goodbye to the ‘Office Mom’
description: If cultivating a certain kind of workplace culture is important, it shouldn’t be extra work that goes uncompensated, researchers say.
content: In May, the chief executive of Washingtonian Media, which publishes a D.C.-area magazine, wrote an opinion essay in which she fretted over “the erosion of office culture” because of remote work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Louisiana High School Sports Meet a Mighty Opponent: Climate Change
description: Repeated hurricanes have devastated the state’s schools, teams and athletic fields. Ida was the latest reminder of the challenges facing the Sportsman’s Paradise.
content: GRAND ISLE, La. — Ida was not yet a hurricane when high school coaches across southern Louisiana began preparing for what had become all too familiar, even inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Afghans With Ties to U.S. Who Could Not Get Out Now Live in Fear
description: Thousands did not make it onto U.S. military evacuation flights. Many of them are now in hiding, worried for their safety and their future.
content: Armed Taliban militants were looking for Shah. They knew he worked as an interpreter for the United States government, and came to his provincial home at night. “Someone inside worked for the U.S. Army!” they shouted, threatening to shoot down the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Fall Travel Trends: Have You Heard of ‘Trip Stacking?’ (You Will.)
description: Uncertainty remains the new normal in travel this autumn driven by the rise in cases and ever-changing travel restrictions, but here are eight things you can expect.
content: After a summer in which travel accelerated rapidly, nearly reaching prepandemic numbers, fall is looking like the season of uncertainty. Increasing concern about the Delta variant, as well as a seasonal travel dip, have slowed bookings. Fear of the variant and the potential of changing regulations have prompted travelers to plan more cautiously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Lauren McCarthy
title: President Biden pledges investment in vaccine components, but will that help the world?
description: President Biden plans to invest $2.7 billion to ramp up U.S. production of critical vaccine components, saying the investment would help make the United States the “arsenal of vaccines for the world.”
content: President Biden plans to invest $2.7 billion to ramp up U.S. production of critical vaccine components, saying the investment would help make the United States the “arsenal of vaccines for the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Doesn’t Contain Any Mint
description: Brendan Emmett Quigley and Paolo Pasco bamboozle us.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — To the surprise of absolutely no one who has ever solved a crossword by Brendan Emmett Quigley, this was a tough one. Mr. Quigley is known for puzzles that are jampacked with pop culture and factoids, most of which — I’m trying to think of a way to say this — probably aren’t that familiar to a majority of New York Times Crossword solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Consumers and Companies Are Buying In on Paying Later
description: Installment payment services are everywhere thanks to fresh deals with Amazon and Square. It’s a simple idea that can quickly get complicated for users.
content: That $128 pair of jeans can now be had for just four payments of $32. Dropping $100 on cosmetics seems less indulgent when the transaction is broken up into $25 payments. Even a pricey Dyson vacuum can be rationalized when purchased in $125 installments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Tyson Foods offers workers more paid time off — if they get vaccinated.
description: Tyson will also compensate workers for “educational sessions about the benefits and risks of the Covid vaccines.”
content: Tyson Foods said it would provide 20 hours of paid sick time a year to fully vaccinated employees to enhance benefits for workers willing to receive coronavirus vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: After delivery workers braved the storm, advocates call for better conditions.
description: Workers fear retaliation from delivery companies if they chose to turn down orders or sign off the app to go home, one advocate said.
content: When Mayor Bill de Blasio urged New Yorkers to stay home and take shelter from the downpour and flooding Wednesday night, one group of people continued to go out: food delivery workers, many of whom were motivated by incentives from delivery apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Tours Hurricane Ida Damage in New Orleans
description: The president has taken pains to show his commitment to the storm response even as his administration deals with the Afghanistan pullout and other critical issues.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden flew to the New Orleans area on Friday to tour the damage wrought by Hurricane Ida, part of an effort to demonstrate his commitment to the federal government’s storm response even as his administration remains enmeshed in other pressing matters from the coronavirus surge to the aftermath of his Afghanistan withdrawal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Simon Romero and Katy Reckdahl
title: Louisiana Nursing Home Residents Describe Squalor at Evacuation Center
description: Hundreds of residents were sent to a warehouse ahead of Hurricane Ida. Sanitation was poor, and they slept on mattresses on the floor.
content: INDEPENDENCE, La. — When Renetta DeRosia called her mother to wish her a happy birthday on Saturday, it seemed as if the phone was not working right. “I can’t hear you,” was all Ms. DeRosia heard from her mother, Loretta Duet, on the other end of the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: This Isn’t Your Grandpa’s Joe Biden
description: The subtle radicalism of Biden’s economic vision.
content: President Biden’s economic policy isn’t what you would have expected from his long career. That’s true in the legislation he’s backing, which is bigger and bolder than anything we’ve seen from him before, but it’s even truer in the appointments he’s making and the theories he’s embracing. On everything from antitrust to inflation to employment to power, Biden is reflecting a new strain of progressive economic thought — one that wants to direct markets, not just correct them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Single, Yet Enjoying the View of Marriage
description: And: childhood sweethearts reunited.
content: Shubnum Khan, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, is 36 and single. Given that she was expected to be married by 25, this is not quite the future she had imagined. And yet she loves her life, and the different type of domestic contentment she has found with her parents, who still make each other — and her —  laugh a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Leader Is Stepping Down. Here’s Who Might Replace Him.
description: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga leaves his party facing its biggest crisis in years, with the coronavirus caseload at record highs and the economy struggling to recover.
content: TOKYO — When Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election as head of Japan’s governing party, the decision created an unexpected opening to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: An Upper East Side Triplex for $60 Million, or $20 Million Over Ask
description: The penthouse, overlooking the Central Park reservoir, was sold by the Swiss financier Jacqui Safra. The closing was the second largest so far this year.
content: One of New York City’s most expensive co-ops has closed, with the sale of a palatial triplex overlooking the Central Park reservoir that was owned by Jacqui Safra, a Swiss financier and producer of several Woody Allen films. At $60 million, it was the biggest transaction in August and second priciest so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Problem When Teams See Athletes as Assets
description: Chelsea and Manchester City have both found ways to monetize their army of spare signings by loaning them out. But should soccer incentivize that, or limit it?
content: One of the things that appealed most to Manchester City about Marlos Moreno was his flexibility. The club spotted him as a teenager, coming off the back of a breakthrough season in which he helped Atlético Nacional, his hometown club in his native Colombia, win not just a national title but the Copa Libertadores, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Felicia Wong
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Felicia Wong. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Felicia Wong. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Gillis
title: Let Your Fridge Go Off for an Hour to Save Our Power Grids
description: Empowering consumers to control their electric consumption would free up power to meet demand elsewhere.
content: In Oregon, some residents are begging electric companies to shut off their power in high winds to prevent the lines from sparking dangerous fires. Power companies that refuse can expect to get sued for keeping the lights on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: From Training Buddies to Life Partners
description: Laura Siegle and A.J. Cephus met through CrossFit. When she left for a monthlong break, he realized that he wanted to take their relationship beyond the gym.
content: Laura Siegle and Ahmaed Cephus Jr. had trained at the same CrossFit gym in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for about a year, engaging in friendly competition and getting to know cursory details about each other’s lives, when Ms. Siegle left for a month in the summer of 2016 on a trip.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Shadow of Elizabeth Holmes and an M.L.B. Team’s History-Making Lineup of Color: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Ernst van de Wetering, Authority and Arbiter on Rembrandt, Dies at 83
description: His decisions on whether a painting was authentic, a copy or an outright fake could jolt the art market. “No one else alive knows as much as he did about Rembrandt.”
content: AMSTERDAM — Ernst van de Wetering, an art historian who was a towering figure in the world of Rembrandt studies and widely regarded as the leading authority on the authenticity of paintings by — or said to be by — Rembrandt, died on Aug. 11 at his home here. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Andrew Sullivan on Being ‘Out on a Limb’
description: Sullivan talks about his collection of essays, and Leila Slimani discusses “In the Country of Others.”
content: “Out on a Limb” is a selection of Andrew Sullivan’s essays from the past 32 years of American history. On this week’s podcast, Sullivan talks about the book and his feelings about some of the very contentious public arguments in which he’s been involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand Police Kill ‘Extremist’ Who Stabbed 6 in ISIS-Inspired Attack
description: The man was under surveillance when he injured six people at a West Auckland supermarket on Friday, officials said. The prime minister called it a “terrorist attack.”
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Six people were injured in a knife attack at a supermarket in New Zealand on Friday, an outburst of violence that the prime minister labeled a “terrorist attack” that had been carried out by a “violent extremist” inspired by the Islamic State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Robert L. James, Globally Minded Ad Man, Dies at 84
description: He took over a storied but struggling agency, McCann Erickson, in the early ’80s and pushed it to become the biggest in the world, with a foot in 99 countries.
content: Robert L. James, who as chief executive of McCann Erickson helped restore its luster as an advertising powerhouse in the 1980s, making it the largest agency in the world, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Iranian commander who said the West deployed lizards as nuke spies dies from Covid-19.
description: The death of Maj. Gen. Hassan Firouzabadi was reported Friday by Iran’s news outlets as the country grapples with its fifth wave of coronavirus infections.
content: A close military aide to Iran’s supreme leader who led the armed forces for 27 years and once accused Western enemies of deploying lizards to spy on Iranian nuclear activities has died from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Change May Be Coming to Your Favorite Wines
description: Rising temperatures and the risk of wildfires have led some wineries to grow different types of grapes. And some regions that were long overlooked are now producing notable wines.
content: The ill effects of climate change on many of the great wine regions in the United States and Europe have only just begun to be felt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: The Storm Warnings Were Dire. Why Couldn’t New York Be Protected?
description: New York City and state officials knew heavy rains were coming, but their preparations couldn’t save the city from death and destruction.
content: The warnings and maps seemed clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Wrestles With Taliban Sanctions as Afghan Crisis Looms
description: The Biden administration must balance maintaining pressure and letting humanitarian aid flow.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s war in Afghanistan is over, but the fight over the Taliban’s finances is only beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Edward J. Greenfield, Judge With a Writerly Touch, Dies at 98
description: He often luxuriated in the richness of the English language, going off on whimsical digressions and enlivening the law with colorful asides.
content: It was a minor legal case in the early 1970s. The New York City Civil Service Commission ruled that a police officer who had missed his Civil Service promotion exam because he was attending his mother-in-law’s funeral could not make up the test because “the deceased was not related.”
source.name: The New York Times

description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Member of Brutal ISIS ‘Beatles’ Cell Pleads Guilty in Hostage Cases
description: Alexanda Kotey admitted that he played a key part in American prisoners’ kidnapping, detention and hostage negotiations. Some of the hostages were beheaded.
content: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A member of a notorious cell of four British Islamic State members who tortured Western hostages pleaded guilty on Thursday in a federal courtroom filled with family members of the group’s American victims, some of whom were beheaded for propaganda videos seen around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Winkie
title: I Was Euphoric in June. Look Where We Are Now.
description: Farewell to the heartbreaking summer of 2021.
content: My girlfriend and I wasted no time this spring. As soon as the Moderna vaccination fever left our bodies in May, we gleefully quadruple-booked every empty weekend left on the calendar. The itinerary swelled beyond precedent. Weddings, birthdays, family reunions and no-occasion rooftop hangs gridlocked into one another, evoking a logistical crisis every evening. I chilled in the cheap seats at Citi Field, sucked in the stale air at the Alamo Drafthouse and drove to both northern and southern Vermont in the span of three weeks. The world was in bloom, and both of us were desperate to witness it firsthand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner and Jennifer Szalai
title: Dread, War and Ambivalence: Literature Since the Towers Fell
description: The Times’s book critics reflect on how 9/11 has influenced writers and readers.
content: The events of 9/11 irrevocably changed the course of global affairs. They also changed culture. It will likely be easier to say how a century from now. But with 20 years’ hindsight, The Times’s book critics reflect below on some of the influence of that day on the writing that has followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: ‘Start Flying Toward the Smoke’: A Wildland Firefighter on Battling Blazes
description: “I feel like our fire season has been longer and I’ve been on more fires little by little every year.”

author: By Karen Zraick
title: What Is Labor Day? A History of the Workers’ Holiday
description: President Grover Cleveland made it a national holiday in 1894, during a crisis over federal efforts to end a strike by railroad workers.
content: In the late 1800s, many Americans toiled 12 hours a day, seven days a week, often in physically demanding, low-paying jobs. Children worked too, on farms and in factories and mines. Conditions were often harsh and unsafe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clarissa Wei
title: The Many Faces of Mooncakes
description: A celebration of the luminous autumn pastry — the signature dish of the Mid-Autumn Festival, which commemorates the full moon and the fall harvest.
content: The cookbook author Betty Liu grew up in a California neighborhood with many Chinese bakeries but could not rely on them to satisfy her mooncake cravings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: What is Apple Thinking?
description: The company’s recent concessions over its App Store could be part of a deliberate strategy to protect more important revenue streams.
content: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Looking Longingly Out Someone Else’s Window
description: Most of our worlds have narrowed down to a single view, but a crowdsourcing website lets us borrow a different one, for a little while.
content: This week, I’ve looked out of the window of a high-rise apartment in Tyumen, Russia, through a skylight in Trorod, Denmark, and out a balcony in Toulouse, France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Becca Foley
title: Is It the Weekend? Not Until He Says So.
description: The 18-year-old behind the viral Twitter account @CraigWeekend has offered people a routine reminder to take a load off.
content: In a scene from “Saturday Night Live,” the English actor Daniel Craig stares into the camera and flops his arms halfheartedly, as if he meant to raise them above his head but got tired halfway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lina Mounzer
title: Lebanon as We Once Knew It Is Gone
description: The standards by which “normal” or “acceptable” living conditions are measured have long been discarded.
content: BEIRUT — I never thought I would live to see the end of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: AstraZeneca settles with the E.U. over delays in vaccine deliveries.
description: A legal fight over undelivered doses lost steam as Europe’s inoculation program ramped up.
content: The European Union reached an agreement with AstraZeneca in a legal battle over delays in the company’s delivery of hundreds of millions of Covid-19 vaccine doses, ending a longstanding dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The U.S. Open Is Alex Molcan’s Proving Ground
description: After seeing one of his junior opponents soar in the rankings while he floundered, Molcan has regained confidence and is in the third round of his first Grand Slam event.
content: Alex Molcan had usually played Andrey Rublev evenly when they competed in junior tournaments for players age 14 and under. Sometimes Rublev won, sometimes it was Molcan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Disabled Japanese Are Often Invisible. Will Paralympics Bring Lasting Light?
description: Tokyo improved its infrastructure before the Games, but activists wonder how long the focus will continue in a country with a long history of excluding people with disabilities.
content: TOKYO — Before ushering in the Paralympic Games, Tokyo undertook a wave of projects to make itself more accessible to people with disabilities. Nearly all train stations now have elevators, and some have safety barriers along platform edges to protect the visually impaired. About 3,200 newly built hotel rooms are wheelchair accessible, as are stalls in many public bathrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Broadway is back, with masks.
content: On Thursday night, the first two musicals returned to Broadway since the theater district went dark on March 12, 2020. Devoted fans — vaccine cards in hand and masks over their noses — filled the seats as “Hadestown” and “Waitress” reopened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Poletto
title: Upstate Motels Make a Comeback, With an Aim to Captivate
description: Once a convenience of the American road trip, these classic motor hotels are being restored as vacation destinations by a new generation of owners.
content: Dana Bowen and her husband, Lindsay Bowen, both 49, initially had been looking to buy a roomy outpost away from New York City that could double as a vacation rental. The couple have a Brooklyn apartment, and a small house in the quaint village of Athens, in Greene County, and habitually scouted Catskill and Hudson Valley property listings looking for “the one” — something big enough to host family and friends, and rent out the rest of the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Gov. Hochul: ‘We have to take action’ to avert future disasters.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul questioned whether more could have been done to warn residents about the danger of flooding from Ida.
content: New York State officials were in the preliminary phases of assessing Ida’s damage on Friday, a day after President Biden approved an emergency declaration that will open up additional federal resources, including $5 million for affected counties.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These two rumors are going viral ahead of California’s recall election.

title: Here’s the current state of transit in the New York region.

content: Two days after the remnants of Hurricane Ida brought torrential flooding and deadly downpours to New York, much of the region’s transit system was back up and running Friday evening.

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Jam and eggs.
content: Welcome. Every Friday, usually around 7 p.m. Eastern, the Twitter user @CraigWeekend posts the same clip. It’s from the March 7, 2020, broadcast of “Saturday Night Live,” and it features the actor Daniel Craig introducing that week’s musical guest, Abel Tesfaye, better known as The Weeknd. “Ladies and gentlemen, The Weeknd,” Craig announces, in a tone that sounds, to me, like pure surrender, like he tried to stop the performance that’s about to occur but it was no use. The Weeknd is going to perform “Blinding Lights,” and we have no choice but to give in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Adria Malcolm
title: A New Kind of Homecoming All Over College Football
description: After the disruptions of 2020, teams from coast to coast are playing in their own stadiums for the first time since 2019.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — Normalcy, or what passes for it these days, started for Louis Trujillo when he arrived around 6 a.m. on Thursday to tailgate at the University of New Mexico. Ordinary came for Yolanda Sanchez when she began her shift in a stadium parking lot at 7 a.m., and for Andrew Erickson, a Lobos wide receiver, as he warmed up in sight of the Sandia Mountains about 10 hours later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster and Raillan Brooks
title: What Does It Look Like When a City Returns to Its Senses?
description: The reopening of New York has created a banquet of sights, smells, flavors, textures and sounds. The New York Times asked photographers to convey how the city is nourishing each of the senses.
content: OK McCausland sought to capture taste. “There’s that moment everyone feels when they’re about to indulge in something they love. I was looking for that moment,” she said — like a group about to dive into a trough of popcorn at a Mets game, or a cut of meat just as it’s being devoured at Katz’s Delicatessen in Manhattan.

content: Last fall, as the rental market floundered, Caleb Valentin decided that the moment had come to move out of his mother’s house in Staten Island and live in Manhattan. author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Love Worth the Phone Bill
description: As teens, Jody Prendergast and Lancelot Ferguson spoke so much on the phone — she in Rosedale, Queens, he in St. Mary Parish, Jamaica — that her father cut the cord. Their connection persisted.
content: Jody Prendergast and Lancelot Ferguson were teenagers when they met in their native St. Mary Parish, Jamaica, in the summer of 2004. Both had jobs at a local medical clinic: Mr. Ferguson was interning in the dental department. Ms. Prendergast was filing papers and filling out immunization cards alongside her best friend, Tara Jo Ferguson (no relation to Mr. Ferguson). Though the girls had spent previous summers playing soccer in the streets and dancing, Ms. Ferguson’s mother was a nurse, and that year she put them to work.

content: Once upon a time, Cinderella dreamed of owning a business. Or so the story goes in Kay Cannon’s new movie, which drags the princess tale into the 21st century with Top-40 pop songs, self-aware dialogue and a trite girlboss sensibility.

title: Europe Doesn’t Want to Fight America’s Battles Anymore
description: But developing military power independent of the United States is going to be hard.
content: To listen to the debate in Europe over the chaotic retreat of United States troops from Afghanistan is to be struck by what a huge vocabulary Europeans have developed over the centuries for describing military calamities. What we just witnessed has already been described as a débâcle, a débandade, a dégringolade and a déroute, not to mention a “rout,” a “fiasco” and a “humiliation.”

I spent more than two weeks not writing newsletters, not editing recipes or thinking about stories to tell, not checking in with correspondents, not clearing my inbox, not doing much of anything productive besides cooking for my family, chasing fish in the surf, chopping aged maple and reading books in the shade.
